Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Reconstructing Central Alaskan Precipitation Variability and Atmospheric Circulation during the Past Millennium
Award.AbstractNarration:
Large-scale atmospheric circulation systems affect the geographic distribution of precipitation in western North America, yet little is known about how these systems may have varied before the instrumental period of the last 150 years. The main goal of this project is to reconstruct the history of precipitation in Alaska during the last thousand years using ice core records of snow accumulation. The researchers plan to collect several new ice cores from the Mt. Hunter Plateau in the Alaska Range of Denali National Park and the new ice cores will be combined with an existing spatial array of ice cores in the region to map changes in the spatial patterns of precipitation. Because changes in atmospheric circulation patterns caused by ENSO and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) affect where the precipitation falls, this spatial array of ice cores will provide a record of how these larger scale climate systems have varied during the last thousand years. The project will focus on determining the differences in the precipitation patterns at the Little Ice Age (approximately 200 to 600 years ago) and Medieval Climate Anomaly (approximately 800 to 1,200 years ago).

This project will evaluate how changes in the climate state affect atmospheric circulation and precipitation. In addition the project includes K-12, undergraduate and graduate education activities, and, in conjunction with the National Park Service, the development of an interactive display showing the climate history of the region and the history of glacier advance and retreat in Denali National Park.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While previous research has provided some understanding of temperature changes in Alaska over the past 1000 years at low elevations, we know much less about how snowfall and temperatures changed high in Alaska’s mountains in the past. This information is important because high-elevation summertime temperature and wintertime snowfall determine the health of Alaska’s glaciers, which are currently retreating and contributing significantly to global sea-level rise under recent warming. Alaskan temperature and snowfall are also closely linked with large-scale climate patterns in the North Pacific, including the changing strength of the Aleutian Low pressure center and the Pacific Decadal Oscillation. Therefore, developing records of past Alaskan temperature and snowfall can clarify how these climate patterns varied under natural conditions over the past millennium, and provide context for their 20th-21st century behavior under rising greenhouse gas concentrations.

 

The main objective of this project was to collect, analyze, and interpret a new ice core record of Alaskan snowfall and high-elevation temperature over the past millennium from Mt. Hunter in Denali National Park. In 2013, a collaborative team of scientists from Dartmouth College, the Universities of New Hampshire and Maine, and the Ice Drilling Program Office successfully collected two parallel ice cores, each 208 m long, through the entire thickness of the Mt. Hunter summit plateau glacier (13,000 feet in elevation). Detailed chemical measurements of the ice cores reveal annual snow layers throughout the cores, allowing us to count individual years back to at least 800 AD. When corrected for density and ice flow, these annual layers reveal that snowfall rates in central Alaska have doubled since 1800 AD, and modern snowfall rates are unprecedented for at least the past 1200 years. The seasonally resolved chronology of the Denali ice core record reveals that 75% of the snowfall increase since 1870 AD has occurred during the winter. We interpret this rise as resulting from a combination of an intensifying Aleutian Low, reflecting increased Alaska storminess, and the increased moisture capacity of the atmosphere as it warmed by approximately 2oC over the past century. We hypothesize that the Aleutian Low may be intensifying as a result of rising greenhouse gas concentrations from human activities. In contrast, during the so-called Medieval Warm Period approximately 800-1000 years ago, our record indicates that the Aleutian Low was considerably weaker, consistent with several other climate records from the region. However, our record is not consistent with global climate model reconstructions of the Aleutian Low over the past millennium, and we suggest that our Denali ice core record can be used as a target to validate climate models.

 

We have also developed a record of past summertime temperatures by measuring the frequency, thickness, and intensity of bubble-free ice layers, representing summertime surface melt, percolation and refreezing, in the Denali ice core. We find that melt layer frequency is higher over the past century than at any other time over the past millennium. Melt frequency and percent were both 20-fold higher from 1900-2012 than from 1700-1900 AD. A detailed analysis of the relationship between Mt. Hunter surface melt production and summertime temperature reveals that a warming of 2-4°C is required to create the 20-fold increase in melt. This is consistent with the magnitude of warming observed in other Alaskan paleoclimate records (e.g. tree-ring records) over the past 200 years associated with natural (rising solar intensity in the early 20th century) and human-caused (rising CO2 concentrations) forcing. This summertime warming has been associated with a substantial retreat of central Alaskan glaciers in recent decades, despite the doubling of wintertime snow accumulation observed over the same period. This demonstrates that central Alaskan glaciers advance and retreat primarily in response to summertime temperatures rather than wintertime snowfall.  

 

The broader impacts of this project include a significant impact on graduate, undergraduate and postdoctoral training and research at Dartmouth. In total, 16 undergraduate students participated in this project at Dartmouth, five of whom participated in fieldwork in Denali National Park, and four of whom conducted research for Senior Honor’s Theses. Half of the undergraduate students are female, and two are from underrepresented groups. In addition, one PhD student focused his dissertation research on this project, and two other Dartmouth graduate students participated in fieldwork. A female Dartmouth postdoctoral fellow led a field expedition and co-mentored two of the undergraduate students. Results were disseminated through 22 presentations at professional meetings, including 8 by undergraduate students, several public lectures in Hanover, NH and Talkeetna, AK, and a number of peer-reviewed publications in final preparation. We are also collaborating with our colleagues at UNH and Colorado State University to develop interactive, inquiry-based K-12 curricula on ice cores and climate change based on this research for distribution through the Denali National Park Murie Science and Learning Center and the New Hampshire Science Teachers Association.
